The most effective way I've found to keep the car cool, is very similar to using the window reflector. You can buy the same aluminized bubblewrap on a roll at a hardware store. What you do is you custom cut a piece for every single window. It only works well if you eliminate all light leaks. I've found that even an inch or two of light leaking in will start greenhousing the inside. When you've done it right, it should pitch black inside the car.

I've used this technique years ago for car camping at a music festival. I had a black car, my camping spot had no shade. I remember waking up one day around noon. I was curious what it was like outside, so I cracked the door open. I was greeted by blindingly bright sunlight, and a waft of very hot air. I quickly slammed the door closed again. The inside of the car was a cool dark sanctuary despite sitting in the baking sun in at high noon. Also conversely, it will help retain heat inside the car if it's cold outside.

This is not the test I would have done. The point of cracking the window is to help the interior of the car remain at ambient air temperature. I would have performed the following test:
1. Early in the day, before the ambient air temperature is already 100F, set up the cars in their test configuration. Also make sure each car is pointed in the same direction (ideally south). Finally, put a thermometer in each car (visible from the outside) to measure the interior temperature without having to open the door.
2. Periodically note the temperature in each car along with the ambient air temperature in both full sun & shade. Expected result is for the temperature in the car with the windows closed to be significantly higher than ambient, near ambient with the windows down, between these two with the windows cracked and hopefully less than ambient with the reflector.

Leaving the car windows open a crack to keep a car cool is a hold over from the time when there were actual vents to the outside located  ear the driver's & passenger's feet. This allowed the air to flow through the vehicle efficiently. Now vehicles are sealed unless a window &/or door is open. Even the heating and cooling system just recirculates the air inside the vehicle.

Any other glass people out there??? For those who noticed the windows looking spotted, it's not dirty, it's actually from the tempering process of the soda lime glass. They run hot glass into cool jets of air to quickly cool the outer layer and build stress into the glass. Those spots you are seeing are areas of different stress and tension. You can usually see this with your eye if you are behind or beside a car at a red light and look through the front windshield.

These things are important otherwise your test is invalid, especially the former. Also, the door flapping test is invalid. You're measuring the temperature of the incoming air, which is very far from the (approximately) equilibrium temperature in the car.

Crack the windows maybe an inch (25.4mm for the rest of the planet).
Drive the first half mile, then switch the A/C to MAX and roll up the windows.

BONUS TIP for those extra-hot days:
Take a spray bottle and wet down the front windshield glass until it's comfortable to touch.
MOST of the heat you feel is radiated heat from the front windshield and dashboard.

ALSO my observations of interiors:
Black seats will make the CAR hot, meaning the latent heat in the car will be worse (take a lot longer to reach equilibrium) whereas white seats will make the AIR hot, which can be vented out allowing you to get to equilibrium much faster... and DON'T opt for leather/vinyl seats if you park outside.
